channel.title: ASF JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [HBASE-7741] Don't use bulk assigner if assigning just several regions
item.description: If just assign one region, bulk assigner may be slower.
item.summary: Don't use bulk assigner if assigning just several regions

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.

comments.comment: @Stack, thanks. I remember you mentioned this before. We should have done so earlier.
Should we make this configurable, so that if there are fewer regions than a given number, don't use bulk assigner?

-1 overall. Here are the results of testing the latest attachment

This message is automatically generated.

Thanks, Ram. I was wondering should we handle not just one region. In small cluster, especially the mini cluster for testing, using bulk assignment has some overhead in creating threads. It is not a big deal. But it could time out some unit test cases, for example, HBASE-7502 (I think it is related to region assignment latency. In mini cluster, all servers are in the same JVM, the thread scheduling may slow down something).

This message is automatically generated.
@Ram, I updated the patch a little. How do you think the new patch? Thanks.

Jimmy Xiang Fancy. Patch looks good to me. One question, you add the flag waitTillAllAssigned... I see it being checked. I don't see it being set when bulk assigning is done. Am I missing something? (Is there a danger we'll wait for ever on bulk assign?)

It is read from configuration and passed to bulk assigner from AM. It won't wait for ever if waitTillAllAssigned is set to true. It will time out in some time if some regions stuck in transition. Since nobody depends on the regions to be assigned, I think it is better to let the bulk assigner run and not to wait for it. This will speed up the starts up a little. If there are several region servers crash at the same time, this can free up the SSH thread a little sooner too.
Integrated into trunk. Thanks Stack and Ram for the review.

Integrated in HBase-TRUNK #3861 (See https://builds.apache.org/job/HBase-TRUNK/3861/)
